StringWithMarkup.String: GROUNDWATER: 1,1-Dichloroethane was detected in the Potomac-Raritan Magothy aquifer system along the Delaware River in SW New Jersey; 6.6% of 315 wells tested positive(1). It was not detected (detection limit 1 ppb) in monitoring wells underlying the Amphenol metal plating plant in Broadview, IL(2). 1,1-Dichloroethane was found in groundwater underlying 7 of 13 municipal Minnesota landfills with suspected groundwater contamination at a concentration of 0.5-1900 ppb but not in 7 others with no suspected contamination (detection limit not specified)(3). Samples of groundwater around Miami Drum Disposal site, Biscayne Aquifer - water supply for Dade County, FL contained concentrations ranging from 2.6 to 14 ppb with the higher concentration at 13-31 meter depth and lower concentration at 3 meters(4). Nine US shallow groundwater samples showed that 5.3% of 208 urban wells sampled contained 1,1-dichloroethane with a maximum concentration of 2.2 ug/L, reporting limit of 0.2 ug/L(5). Results of a 1996 study showed that 1,1-dichloroethane was detected in groundwater from the Glassboro region of Southern New Jersey at a detection frequency of 5%, and at a concentration greater than 0.1 ug/L(6). Groundwater samples near the Orange County Florida landfill in 1989-1993 contained 1,1-dichloroethane concentrations of 0.07-10.84 ug/L(7). In a survey of groundwater conducted by the US federal agencies in 9 states, a maximum concentration of 11,330 ug/L was reported; 18 % of samples were positive(8). Groundwater samples (well water) collected from industrial sites in Taiwan in 1999 contained 1,1-dichloroethane levels of 900-1000 ug/L(9).

Reference: (1) Barkley J et al; Biomed Mass Spectrom 7: 139-47 (1980)
(2) Westrick JJ et al; J Amer Water Works Assoc 76: 52-9 (1984)

StringWithMarkup.String: DRINKING WATER: 1,1-Dichloroethane was not detected in drinking water of Love Canal residents(1). In a US Groundwater Supply Survey of 954 supplies derived from groundwater chosen both randomly and on the basis that they may contain VOC's, 41 samples tested positive for 1,1-dichloroethane with a 0.6 ppb median concentration of positives and a 4.2 ppb maximum(2). Bank-filtered tap water from the Rhine River in the Netherlands contained a maximum 1,1-dichloroethane concentration of 500 parts per trillion(3). The compound was detected in 30 Canadian treatment plants, all serving large centers of population, at a <1 ppb concentration, with 2 and 3% detection frequency in raw and treated water, respectively, during Aug-Sept 1979(4); <1 ppb concentration, with 0 and 2% detection frequency in raw and treated water, respectively, during Nov-Dec 1979(4). Studies in the UK reported 1,1-dichloroethane was detected in 1 of 14 water supplies tested(5); the sample source was a river/lowland reservoir(5). According to US federal studies, 21.4% of monitored drinking water wells contained 1,1-dichloroethane(6). In Iowa, where 127 wells from 58 public water supplies were analyzed, 5 wells from four different public water supplies contained residues of 1-24 ppb 1,1-dichloroethane(7). A polluted drinking water well in Maine contained a 1,1-dichloroethane concentration of 7 ppb(8). It was detected, not quantified, in 11 of 1000 Wisconsin wells(9). Drinking water in New Jersey contained 105-142 ng/L(10). A US Geological Survey of 954 community water systems (1999-2000) detected 1,1-dichloroethane in 11 of 956 samples (detection limit of 0.036 ug/L)(11). 1,1-Dichloroethane was detected in 2.3% of 130 groundwater well samples collected during 2008 and 2009 from five alluvial plains in East China at a maximum concentration of 0.6 ug/L(12). A California analysis of 13,347 California groundwater sources of drinking water found 1,1-dichloroethane in 68 samples with concentrations ranging from 0.51 to 30 ppb(13); 1,1-dichloroethane was not found in any of the 754 surface water sources of drinking water sampled(13). In a US Geological Survey assessment of the quality of source water from public supply wells in the United States from 1993 to 2007, 1,1-dichloroethane was detected in 7.7% of 832 samples, and 1.4% of the samples contained greater than or equal to 0.2 ug/L(13); the maximum concentration of 1,1-dichloroethane detected was 4.878 ug/L(13).

Reference: (1) USEPA; Monitoring the Occurrence of Unregulated Drinking Water Contaminants. Available from, as of April 10, 2018: https://www.epa.gov/dwucmr

(2) USEPA; The Third Unregulated Contaminant Monitoring Rule (UCMR 3): Data Summary October 2015. Available from, as of April 10, 2018: https://www.epa.gov/dwucmr/third-unregulated-contaminant-monitoring-rule

StringWithMarkup.String: DRINKING WATER: The USEPA Unregulated Contaminant Monitoring Rule (UCMR3) program monitors for 30 contaminants (including 1,1-dichloroethane) in PWSs (public water systems)(1). All PWSs serving more than 10,000 people and 800 representative PWSs serving 10,000 or fewer people were monitoring contaminants during a 12-month period from January 2013 through December 2015. For 1,1- dichloroethane (MRL of 0.03 ug/L), the October 2015 Data Summary reports that 764 monitoring results, from a total of 32,891 results, detected 1,1-dichloroethane at or above the MRL(2).

StringWithMarkup.String: SURFACE WATER: Samples were taken from the Lake Ontario Basin and 1,1-dichloroethane was detected in a Genesee River sample but absent in both a Niagara River sample and open water sample from Lake Ontario(1). Samples from 8 stations on the Ohio River mainstream and 3 on tributaries, a total of 4,972 samples, collected during 1980-1981 were analyzed for 1,1-dichloroethane(2); 156 (3.1%) were positive of which 122 were between 0.1 and 1.0 ppb, 33 between 1.0 and 10 ppb, and 1 >10 ppb(2). Samples from the Ohio River System, collected during 1978-1979 from 8 stations for a total of 842 samples on mainstream and 2 stations, a total of 235 samples on tributaries reported 1,1-dichloroethane concentrations as follows: 3.9% of mainstream samples had detectable levels of 1,1-dichloroethane that were <1.0 ppb and 5.3% of tributary samples had detectable levels that were <1.0 ppb and 0.3% that were between 1.0 and 10.0 ppb(3). In a survey of surface water conducted by the US federal agencies in 9 states, a maximum concentration of 0.2 ug/L was reported; 18 % of samples were positive(4). Raw water for 30 Canadian water treatment plants contained a mean 1,1-dichloroethane concentration of 2 ppb, 33 ppb max, with a 19% detection frequency in Aug-Sept 1979; <1.0 ppb mean, 11 ppb max, 13% detection frequency in Nov-Dec 1979(5). In an analysis of 644 surface water samples collected in Portugal between April 1999 to May 2000, 1,1-dichloroethane was detected in only 13 samples (detection limit of 0.09 ug/L)(5); levels of 1-7 ug/L were detected in waters near industrial areas(6). Analysis of water samples collected from rivers and estuaries near Osaka Japan during 1993-1995 found 1,1-dichloroethane concentrations of 0.2-1.1 ug/L(7).

Reference: (1) Novak J et al; J Chromatogr 76: 45-50 (1973)

StringWithMarkup.String: DRINKING WATER: Dichloroethane was present in an unspecified sample of polluted drinking water at a concentration of 6.1X10 mg/L(1).

Section.Description: Concentration of this compound in effluent.  Effluent is wastewater (treated or untreated) discharged into surface waters from a treatment plant, sewer, or industrial outfall.

Reference: (1) Allen MR et al; Environ Sci Technol 31: 1054-61 (1997)

(2) ATSDR; Toxicological Profile for 1,1-Dichloroethane. Atlanta, GA: Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry, US Public Health Service (2015). Available from, as of April 10, 2018: https://www.atsdr.cdc.gov/toxprofiles/index.asp
(3) Baker RJ et al; J Environ Qual 41: 1324-1336 (2012)
(4) Witkowska D; Br Poult Sci 54: 289-297 (2013)

StringWithMarkup.String: Analysis of landfill gas samples from 7 United Kingdom waste landfill facilities accepting both domestic and trade waste showed 1,1-dichloroethane concentrations ranging from <0.1 to 62 mg/cu m(1). 1,1-Dichloroethane has been identified in at least 673 of the 1,699 hazardous waste sites that have been proposed for inclusion on the EPA National Priorities List as of 2007(2). Estimated releases of 20,972 pounds (9.51 metric tons) of 1,1-dichloroethane to the atmosphere from 19 domestic manufacturing and processing facilities in 2013, accounted for about 90.1% of the estimated total environmental releases from facilities required to report to the EPA Toxic Release Inventory (TRI) Program(2). 1,1-Dichloroethane was detected with the volatile organic compounds emanating from a low-level radioactive waste disposal facility at the US Geological Survey (USGS) Amargosa Desert Research Site in Nevada(3). In 2011, 1,1-dichloroethane was detected in the gaseous emissions of a commercial poultry farm in Poland with average levels on the order of 1 ppm in turkey houses(4).

Reference: (1) Sabel GV, Clark TP; Waste Manag Res 2: 119-30 (1984)
(2) Cole RH et al; J Water Pollut Control Fed 56: 898-908 (1984)
(3) USEPA; Treatability Manual I Treatability Data USEPA-600/2-82-001A (1981)
(4) Young DR et al; Water Chlorination, Environ Impact Health Eff 4(Book 2): 871-84 (1983)
(5) Lesage S et al; pp. 88-97 in Proc Ontario Ministry Environ. Technol Transfer Conf. Toronto, Ontario, Canada. Vol 2. (1989)

StringWithMarkup.String: 1,1-Dichloroethane was detected in municipal landfill leachate in Minnesota and Wisconsin, with 9 of 13 samples positive at a concentration of 0.5-6300 ppb(1). National Urban Runoff Program in which 86 samples from 19 cities throughout the US were analyzed reported 4% of samples positive, 1.5-3 ppb, detected only in Long Island, NY and Eugene, OR(2). Treated waste water from the following industries contained 1,1-dichloroethane (industry (mean concentration)): coil coating (10 ppb); nonferrous metals manufacturing (0.6 ppb); organic chemical manufacturing/plastics (9.1 ppb); paint formulation (95 ppb); rubber processing (56 ppb)(3). Additionally, untreated wastewater from the following industries contained 1,1-dichloroethane (industry (mean concentration)): battery manufacturing (10 ppb); metal finishing (480 ppb); pharmaceutical manufacturing (13 ppb); and pulp and paperboard mills (12 ppb)(3). It was not detected in the final effluents of the Los Angeles City (Hyperion), Orange County, CA (OCSD), and San Diego City (Point Loma) treatment plants at a detection limit of 10 parts per trillion(4); it was detected in Los Angeles County Joint Water Pollution Control Plant municipal wastewater (final effluent) at a concentration of 3.5 ppb(4). Municipal landfill leachates collected from Muskokas and Guelph, Ontario, Canada were collected and analyzed for volatile compounds in 1989 (Muskokas) and in 1988, 1989 (Guelph); 1,1-dichloroethane was detected at 25, and 43 and 108 ug/L, respectively(5).

Section.Description: Concentrations of this compound in sediment/soil.

Reference: (1) Young DR et al; Water Chlorination, Environ Impact Health Eff 4(Book 2): 871-84 (1983)
(2) Hauser TR, Bromberg SM; Environ Monit Assess 2: 249-72 (1982)

StringWithMarkup.String: SEDIMENT: 1,1-Dichloroethane was not detected in bottom sediment of the submarine outfall region of the Los Angeles County (JWPCP) municipal wastewater treatment plant at a detection limit of 0.5 ppb(1). It was detected, not quantified in Love Canal, NY sediment samples(2).

Reference: (1) Hauser TR, Bromberg SM; Environ Monit Assess 2: 249-72 (1982)

StringWithMarkup.String: SOIL: 1,1-Dichloroethane was detected, not quantified, in Love Canal, NY soil(1).

Section.Description: Concentrations of this compound in the atmosphere.

Reference: (1) USEPA; Ambient Monitoring Technology Information Center, Air Toxics - Data Analysis. Available from, as of April 10, 2018: https://www3.epa.gov/ttnamti1/toxdat.html

(2) ATSDR; Toxicological Profile for 1,1-Dichloroethane. Atlanta, GA: Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry, US Public Health Service (2015). Available from, as of April 10, 2018: https://www.atsdr.cdc.gov/toxprofiles/index.asp

StringWithMarkup.String: The Air Quality System (AQS) database is the US EPA repository of criteria air pollutants and hazardous air pollutants (HAPs) containing monitoring data from over 2,600 monitoring sites across the United States(1,2). For 2013, in general nationwide, the average concentration of the samples for 1,1-dichloroethane in outdoor air was approximately 0.02 ug/cu m(2). The highest reported concentration (4.4 ug/cu m) occurred in one sample from Kentucky. The second highest reported concentration (0.83 ug/cu m) also occurred in one sample from Kentucky. The third highest reported concentration (0.81 ug/cu m) was detected in 173 samples from Ohio. Rhode Island had the largest number of samples with detectable concentrations, 836 samples, that ranged in concentration from 0.004 to 0.12 ug/cu m. The 24-hour average concentration of 1,1-dichloroethane in outdoor air ranged from approximately 0.008 to 3.5 ug/cu m (0.001-1.09 ppb)(2).

Reference: (1) Brodzinsky R, Singh HB; Volatile Organic Chem in the Atmos, An Assess of Available Data; Menlo Park, CA: Atmos Sci Centr, SRI Internatl 68-02-3452 pp. 198 (1982)
(2) USEPA: Formulation of a Preliminary Assessment of Halogenated Organic Compounds in Man and Environmental Media p447 (1979) EPA-560/13-79-006
(3) Islam MA, Stancheva E; Water, Air, and Soil Pollution 115: 309-320 (1999)
(4) Mohamed MF et al; Chemosphere 47: 863-882 (2002)
(5) Thijssa TR et al; J Air & Waste Manage Assoc 49: 1394-1404 (1999)
(6) Kim KH et al; Environ Eng Sci 29(9): 875-889 (2012)

StringWithMarkup.String: URBAN/SUBURBAN: 1,1-Dichloroethane was detected in 455 US samples at a median concentration of 61 parts per trillion, 110 parts per trillion max(1). In Baton Rouge, LA air contained trace to 500 ng/cu m and in Houston TX air contained trace to 555 ng/cu m(2). Monitoring conducted between Aug 1995 to Sept 1996 in Rousse, Bulgaria detected 1,1-dichloroethane in 41 of 256 air samples (detection limit not reported)(3). Ambient air samples collected at 13 urban locations in the US between Sept 1996 and Aug 1997 detected 1,1-dichloroethane at concentrations less than 1 ppbv(4). Air monitoring conducted in Berlin Germany in the summer of 1996 detected an average 1,1-dichloroethane concentration of 0.06 ug/cu m(5). From February to December 2009, 1,1-dichloroethane was detected in ambient air samples from four sites in Seoul, Korea (Jong Ro, Yang Jae, Gwang Jin, and Gang Seo) at concentrations of 0.04-0.18, 0.03-0.08, 0.04-0.15, and 0.04-0.32 ppb, respectively(6).

Reference: (1) Brodzinsky R, Singh HB; Volatile Organic Chem in the Atmos, An Assess of Available Data; Menlo Park, CA: Atmos Sci Centr, SRI Intnatl 68-02-3452 pp. 198 (1982)
(2) Grimsrud EP, Rasmussen RA; Atmos Environ 9: 1014-7 (1975)
(3) Thijssa TR et al; J Air Waste Manage Assoc 49: 1394-1404 (1999)

StringWithMarkup.String: RURAL/REMOTE: 1,1-Dichloroethane was not detected in 2 US samples, locations not specified(1). It was reported in samples from Southwest Washington at a concentration of <5 parts per trillion(2). Air monitoring conducted at a rural site in Germany in the summer of 1996 detected an average 1,1-dichloroethane concentration of 0.06 ug/cu m(3).

Reference: (1) Brodzinsky R, Singh HB; Volatile Organic Chem in the Atmos, An Assess of Available Data; Menlo Park, CA: Atmos Sci Centr, SRI Internatl 68-02-3452 pp. 198 (1982)
(2) Pellizzari ED; Environ Sci Technol 16: 781-5 (1982)
(3) Barkley J et al; Biomed Mass Spectrom 7: 139-47 (1980)

StringWithMarkup.String: SOURCE DOMINATED: 1,1-Dichloroethane was detected in 101 US samples at a median concentration of 11 parts per trillion, 1,400 parts per trillion max(1). Ambient air surrounding Kin-Buc Waste disposal site in Edison NJ contained 23 ug/cu m(2). It was not detected in air outside the homes of Love Canal, NY residents(3). 1,1-Dichloroethane was detected, not quantified in Baton Rouge, LA where many organic chemicals and petroleum facilities are located(2).

Reference: (1) Heikes DL et al; J Agric Food Chem 43: 2869-2875 (1995)

(2) ATSDR; Toxicological Profile for 1,1-Dichloroethane. Atlanta, GA: Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry, US Public Health Service (2015). Available from, as of April 10, 2018: https://www.atsdr.cdc.gov/toxprofiles/index.asp

StringWithMarkup.String: 1,1-Dichloroethane was not detected in 234 table-ready food items from the US FDA's Total Diet Study (10.7 ppb limit of detection)(1). 1,1-Dichloroethane was detected in three peanut butter samples at levels of 1.1, 1.9, and 3.7  g/kg, however, the compound was not found in several other foods that were analyzed(2).

Section.Description: Concentrations of this compound in fish or seafood.

Reference: (1) Young DR et al; Water Chlorination; Environ Impact Health Eff 4(Book 2): 871-84 (1983)
(2) Ferrario JB et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 34: 246-55 (1985)

StringWithMarkup.String: 1,1-Dichloroethane was not detected (detection limit 0.3 ppb) in whole invertebrates, fish liver, or shrimp muscle obtained from a station off the submarine outfall of the Los Angeles County (JWPCP) municipal treatment plant(1). In shellfish samples from Lake Pontchartrain, New Orleans, the Mississippi River delta, the mean concentration in oysters was 33 parts per trillion(2); not detected in clams(2).

Reference: (1) Staples CA et al; Environ Tox Chem 4: 131-42 (1985)

StringWithMarkup.String: Results reported in the STORET database for dichloroethanes are as follows: fish tissue: Lower Mississippi (2 samples) and Western Gulf (3 samples) - not detected; Pacific Northwest (37 samples) 0.05-20 ppm, 0.7 ppm average; Alaska (6 samples) 0.05 ppm average and maximum(1).

Section.Description: Other environmental concentrations reported for this chemical.

Reference: (1) Odabasi M; Environ Sci Technol 42: 1445-1451 (2008)

StringWithMarkup.String: Headspace analysis of air emissions from eight different household bleach products during use detected 1,1-dichloroethane concentrations of 0.7 to 176 ug/cu m; it was suggested that sodium hypochlorite (NaOCl) in the bleach may react to generate halogenated volatile organic compounds(1).

Reference: (1) Wang et al; Aerosol Air Qual Res 12(6):1269-1281 (2012)

StringWithMarkup.String: Emissions from six commercial cigarette brands were examined in a chamber study; five cigarettes per brand were smoked for approximately 6 minutes. The amount of 1,1-dichloroethane emitted during smoking ranged between 51 and 110 ug/cigarette. The average concentration of 1,1-dichloroethane during smoking ranged from 12 to 26 ug/cu m and the average concentration during the post-smoking period ranged from 7.9 to 17 ug/cu m(1).

Section.Description: Potential way(s) in which people may come into contact with a hazardous chemical.  Examples of common exposure routes are inhalation, ingestion, skin/eye contact.

Reference: (1) US EPA; Chemical Data Reporting (CDR). Non-confidential 2016 Chemical Data Reporting information on chemical production and use in the United States. Available from, as of April 10, 2018: https://chemview.epa.gov/chemview

StringWithMarkup.String: According to the 2016 TSCA Inventory Update Reporting data, 2 reporting facilities estimate the number of persons reasonably likely to be exposed in the manufacturing, processing, or use of 1,1-dichloroethane in the United States may be as low as 50 workers up to the range of 500 workers per plant; the data may be greatly underestimated due to confidential business information (CBI) or unknown values(1).

Reference: (1) CDC; International Chemical Safety Cards (ICSC) 2012. Atlanta, GA: Centers for Disease Prevention & Control. National Institute for Occupational Safety & Health (NIOSH). Ed Info Div. Available from, as of April 10, 2018: https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/ipcs/default.html

(2) ATSDR; Toxicological Profile for 1,1-Dichloroethane. Atlanta, GA: Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry, US Public Health Service (2015). Available from, as of April 10, 2018: https://www.atsdr.cdc.gov/toxprofiles/index.asp
(3) Odabasi M; Environ Sci Technol 42: 1445-1451 (2008)

StringWithMarkup.String: NIOSH (NOES Survey 1981-1983) has statistically estimated that 1,957 workers (272 of these are female) are potentially exposed to 1,1-dichloroethane in the US(1). Occupational exposure to 1,1-dichloroethane may occur through inhalation and dermal contact with this compound at workplaces where 1,1-dichloroethane is produced or used(SRC). Monitoring data indicate that the general population may be exposed to 1,1-dichloroethane via inhalation of ambient air, ingestion of contaminated drinking water, and dermal contact with consumer products containing 1,1-dichloroethane(SRC). Inhalation exposure to the general population can exist for those people living near source areas(2) and during use of household bleach products(3).

Reference: International Labour Office. Encyclopedia of Occupational Health and Safety. Vols. I&II. Geneva, Switzerland: International Labour Office, 1983., p. 795

StringWithMarkup.String: ... The most likely chance of exposure occurs during the pouring of containers of ethylene dichloride into open vats where it is subsequently used for the fumigation of grain. Exposures also occur through manufacturing losses, application of paints, solvent extractions, and waste disposal operations.

StringWithMarkup.String: A trace of 1,1-dichloroethane was found in exhaled air from 1 of 9 Love Canal, NY residents tested(1). A trace of 1,1-dichloroethane was found on the breath of 8 healthy volunteers employed at the US Air Force School of Aerospce Medicine, TX that had no special exposure to chemicals(2).

Reference: (1) ATSDR; Toxicological Profile for 1,1-Dichloroethane. Atlanta, GA: Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry, US Public Health Service (2015). Available from, as of Jan 11, 2016: https://www.atsdr.cdc.gov/toxprofiles/index.asp

StringWithMarkup.String: A National Health and Nutrition Survey (NHANES) of the U.S. population in 2003-2004 screened for 1,1-dichloroethane in blood from 1,367 participants (670 males and 679 females) in the age range of 20-59 years old; the portion of the data below the limit of detection (LOD of 0.01 ug/L) was too high to provide valid results for a background level in blood(1). The geometric mean of the 2005-2006 NHANES sampling of blood from 3,193 participants was <0.01 ug/L (limit of detection(1).

Literature references related to scientific contents from Springer Nature journals and books. These references have been ranked automatically by an algorithm which calculates the relevance for each substance in a Springer Nature document. It is based on: (1) the TF-IDF, adapted to chemical structures, (2) location information in the text (e.g. title, abstract, keywords), and (3) the document size.  Springer Nature aims to provide only highly qualitative and relevant content but references of lower relevance aren't withheld as they might contain also very useful information.

ChEBI Ontology tree.  ChEBI is an acronym for Chemical Entities of Biological Interest, which is a freely available dictionary of molecular entities focused on 'small' chemical compounds. Classification of this compound, provided by ChemIDplus, which is a free web search system that provides access to the structure and nomenclature authority files used for the identification of chemical substances cited in National Library of Medicine (NLM) databases. A classification from the NORMAN Suspect List Exchange, which serve as a central access point to find lists of chemicals with environmental concerns.

Classification from the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's Distributed Structure-Searchable Toxicity (DSSTox) database. DSSTox provides a high quality public chemistry resource for supporting improved predictive toxicology. A distinguishing feature of this effort is the accurate mapping of bioassay and physicochemical property data associated with chemical substances to their corresponding chemical structures.

EPA Chemicals under the Toxic Substances Control Act (TSCA) collection contains information on chemicals and their regulation under TSCA. The chemical classification tree is created based on the TSCA substance regulatory flag, UVCB, and commercial activity status.

Substance Registry Services (SRS) is the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) central system for information about substances that are tracked or regulated by EPA or other sources. It is a resource for basic information about chemicals, biological organisms, and other substances of interest to EPA and its state and tribal partners. SRS makes it possible to identify which EPA data systems, environmental statutes, or other sources have information about a substance and which synonym is used by that system or statute.

EPA Chemicals under the Toxic Substances Control Act (TSCA) collection contains information on chemicals and their regulation under TSCA. The chemical classification tree is created based on the TSCA substance regulatory flag, UVCB, and commercial activity status.
Update: 2024-12-06 12:51:01

Reference.Name: MolGenie Organic Chemistry Ontology
Reference.Description: An organic chemistry ontology developed by MolGenie and OntoChem to assign chemical entities to structural classes, split into three main subsections: calculated properties, compounds and substructural concepts. The ontology contains chemistry structural classes with a focus on elements and small organic compounds, but not inorganic, polymer, biopolymer, metal complexes, metal organic frameworks (MOFs) and other chemistry entities. The ontology has been mapped to several collections of chemicals, including (a) Chemicals of Biological Interest (ChEBI), (b) the ChEMBL database of bioactive molecules, (c) the LOTUS natural product collection, (d) per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) extracted from Barnabas et al (2022) DOI: 10.1039/D2DD00019A (e) PubChemLite and (f) the ZeroPM Global Chemical Inventory.

Reference.Name: SID 403030186
Reference.Description: The PATENTSCOPE database from WIPO includes patent and chemical structure search (with a free account) that gives access to millions of patent documents. The World Intellectual Property Organisation (WIPO) is a specialized United Nations (UN) agency headquartered in Geneva (Switzerland). Our mission is to lead the development of a balanced and effective international Intellectual Property (IP) system that enables innovation and creativity for the benefit of all. We help governments, businesses and society realize the benefits of Intellectual Property and are notably a world reference source for IP information.
